I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Tashkent Province Sewerage Improvement Project. The report 
also describes the proposed administration of technical assistance (TA) to be provided by the 
Spanish Cooperation Fund for Technical Assistance and the Republic of Korea e-Asia and 
Knowledge Partnership Fund for Institutional Capacity Support for Modern Utility Management, 
and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the 
Board, approve the administration of the TA. 
2.  The project takes an integrated approach to improving the access to and reliability of water 
supply and sanitation (WSS) services in Tashkent Province; and will strengthen climate resilience, 
gender equality, and environmental sustainability for a green and inclusive recovery after the 
coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic.  It  will  achieve  this  by  (i)  enhancing  sewerage 
coverage in cities; (ii) improving decentralized sanitation in rural areas; (iii) installing production 
and consumption water meters; (iv) supporting comprehensive capacity building of the Tashkent 
Suvtaminot (TST), the provincial WSS utility; (v) preventing the spread of COVID-19 through 
gender-friendly awareness campaigns for water, sanitation, hygiene, and health (WASH+H) 
measures; and (vi) engaging civil society for broad citizen participation. 
II.  THE PROJECT  
A.  Rationale 
3.  Macroeconomic situation and COVID-19 recovery. Uzbekistan is a lower middle-
income country and one of Central Asia’s fastest-growing economies, achieving a consistent 
annual growth rate of 4%–6%, with real gross domestic product (GDP) increasing from 4.4% in 
2017 to 5.4% in 2018 and expanding to 5.8% in 2019.1 The Government of Uzbekistan is 
undertaking  structural  reforms focused  on  economic  diversification,  attracting  foreign  direct 
investment, and balancing urban and rural development. While GDP growth in 2020 decreased 
sharply to 1.6% because of COVID-19 impacts, it is projected to increase by 5.0% in 2021 and 
5.3% in 2022.2 About 448,000 or 1.3% of the population are estimated to have fallen into poverty 
because of the COVID-19 crisis, despite the government’s substantial measures to boost health 
spending and support households and firms.3 The COVID-19 impacts to public health are 
exacerbated by limited WSS services and poor sanitation. 
4.  Investment in WSS services is an essential part of the government’s development and 
COVID-19 recovery strategy.4 Less than 20% of the population has access to adequate WSS 
services, and the country has an estimated WSS infrastructure deficit of $2.9 billion.5 Despite 
recent investments by international financial institutions, large gaps remain to be able to upgrade 
the country’s legacy WSS infrastructure. This has resulted in environmental and public health 
risks undermining livability and constraining the country’s economic potential.

5.  Project area. Tashkent Province is the country’ economic engine, generating almost 25% 
of the country’s GDP. It is the largest urban agglomeration, with 3.1 million people spread across 
7 cities, 14 districts, 97 semi-urbanized settlements, and 885 rural settlements. 
6.  Key issues. Despite its strong economic potential, Tashkent Province is hindered by 
pervasive limitations in sanitation coverage and services, aggravated by an increasing urban 
population. Only 17% of the province’s population is connected to sewerage systems, while the 
remaining 83% rely on pit latrines and earth ditches—practices that threaten public health and 
environmental quality.6 The sewerage system in the urban areas has not expanded since 1991, 
resulting in a service coverage of only 35%. The wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) and 
networks are no longer functional. Rural settlements have no wastewater services. As a result, 
massive quantities of untreated wastewater (up to 80% of the total volume) are discharged to the 
environment. Water quality in the province is deteriorating, and pollution levels exceed national 
standards. This is compounded by the decline in river flows caused by climate change. In addition, 
the expected rise in temperature will increase stress on materials and biological treatments. Key 
issues include limited operation and maintenance (O&M) capacity, an unattractive environment 
for private sector participation, and low metering and tariff levels.7 Water supply losses, estimated 
at 38%, are difficult to verify because of limited water metering. The wastewater tariff is below 
cost recovery levels, hindering O&M and service delivery.8 
7.  Institutional performance and reforms. Since its reorganization in 2016, TST and its 
2,770 staff—serving about 340,600 water supply and 170,000 sewerage connections—have 
implemented a series of reforms addressing critical needs. Two ongoing water supply projects 
financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) have helped support these reforms in the 
province.9  These  include  consolidated  smaller  water  supply  systems,  strengthened  public 
accountability, modernized management systems, expanded coverage, increased tariffs, and 
improved staffing. However, TST’s operational performance still lags in corporate management, 
customer  service  standards,  industrial  sewer  inspection,  nonrevenue  water  management, 
outsourcing contracts, and wastewater management. Smart water management solutions, such 
as information and communication technology, geographic information systems, smart water 
metering, supervisory control and data acquisition systems, and geographic information system-
based data for asset management and O&M, will improve its operational capacity. A clear 
institutional road map is needed to guide TST’s medium- to long-term corporate development for 
optimal and sustainable service delivery to customers.  
8.  In November 2019, the government formed a national water agency—Uzsuvtaminot Joint 
Stock Company (UJSC)—to strengthen WSS. The suvokovas (provincial utilities), including TST, 
under the Ministry of Housing and Communal Services, have been transferred to UJSC.10 This 
reform is expected to enable private sector participation and improve efficiencies. UJSC is the 
parent company for all suvokovas, responsible for tariff collection, sector planning, and the

expected to improve the performance of ADB-funded projects because of its strong coordination 
with suvokovas. The ADB project coordination unit (PCU), which implements ongoing ADB-

9.  ADB’s phased investment approach in Tashkent Province. ADB is implementing two 
WSS improvement projects in the province (footnote 9). The first, approved in 2016, aims to 
increase access to piped drinking water from 20% of the rural population in two districts to 100% 
by 2023. The second, approved in 2019, aims to (i) expand water supply for rural populations 
from less than 20% to 100% in two more districts, and (ii) address rural sanitation needs by 
providing septic tanks in selected rural settlements. The project will complement these ongoing 
projects to fill essential sanitation infrastructure and service gaps and  to strengthen TST’s 
institutional capacity in WSS services.13  
10.  Strategic alignment. The project is aligned with Uzbekistan’s national development 
strategy, 2017–2021 for inclusive and sustainable growth and access to basic urban services.14 It 
also supports government decrees on WSS and ADB’s Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020.15 
The project is in line with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Uzbekistan, 2019–2023, which 
aims to bridge the gap between rural and urban development.16 It is also aligned with ADB's 
Strategy 2030 operational priorities.17 
11.  Development partner coordination. ADB is the lead WSS development partner in 
Uzbekistan. The World Bank and the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation are 
involved in WSS projects in Tashkent Province. The Agence Française de Développement, the 
Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, and the Islamic Development Bank are also involved in 
WSS. Close coordination in sector investments and policy dialogue is regularly practiced. 
12.  Lessons. Key lessons from ongoing and past ADB-financed WSS projects in the country 
include the need for (i) engaging the private sector in O&M with transfer of skills, (ii) providing 
institutional capacity support for sustainability, (iii) installing sewer connections, (iv) achieving high 
procurement readiness using project readiness financing (PRF), and (v) encouraging long-term 
policy dialogue and partnership for strategic investments to achieve sustainable outcomes.18

14.  Impact and outcome. The project is aligned with the following impact: environment, 
health, and living conditions in Tashkent Province improved (project defined). The project will 
have the following outcome: reliable, sustainable, and affordable wastewater services in six cities 
and one urban center improved and expanded; and affordable decentralized wastewater disposal 
and services in rural areas of three districts established.21 
15.  Output  1:  Inclusive  urban  and  rural  sanitation  systems  with  climate-resilient 
features developed. This output includes (i) centralized urban wastewater systems in the six 
cities of Akhangaran, Almalyk, Angren, Bekabod, Chirchik, and Yangiyul, and Chinaz urban 
center improved, by (a) rehabilitating and upgrading four WWTPs, and constructing one new 
WWTP, with a combined capacity of 392,000 cubic meters (m3/day);22 (b) rehabilitating and 
constructing 114 kilometers of sewerage collectors and 238 kilometers of sewerage networks with 
new sewer connections; and (c) installing 50,000 water meters and 1,028 bulk water meters;23 
and (ii) decentralized wastewater systems in 70 rural settlements in Chinaz, Yangiyul, and 
Zangiota districts established by (a) installing 23,500 individual septic tank systems, (b) providing 
O&M equipment, (c) operationalizing a fecal sludge management unit, (d) formulating a fecal 
sludge management program to rationalize and expand septage collection and disposal services, 
and (e) implementing a public WASH+H awareness program. 
16.  Output  2:  Institutional  capacity  for  sustainable  sanitation  services  delivery 
strengthened. This output includes capacity development of TST through corporate development 
training and coaching in business planning; corporate governance; asset management; human 
resources  management,  including  gender  policies  and  sensitization  training;  financial 
management; customer relationship management; technical wastewater management; O&M 
management; and environmental monitoring. In addition, treatment plant managers and O&M 
operators in the project areas will receive training provided by design–build contractors. 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
17.  ADB value addition includes the following: 
(i)  Holistic and inclusive approach. The project will develop an integrated sanitation 
system comprising centralized and decentralized sanitation systems to provide full 
coverage in the project area. The sanitation system will also include a modern 
septic tank collection and disposal system outside central networks. 
(ii)  Institutional support for sustainability. The project includes an institutional road 
map with concrete measures to establish TST as a model utility for Uzbekistan. 
The project will (a) develop a management information system for TST to improve 
performance management and decision-making; (b) improve customer service

agency for the project, operating under UJSC. It will be (i) the employer in all contracts, (ii) the

III.  ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
23.  The attached TA will support TST in implementing institutional reforms and capacity-
building programs following its institutional development road map.32 The TA is estimated to cost 
$800,000, of which (i) $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis by Spanish Cooperation Fund 
for Technical Assistance; and (ii) $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis by Republic of Korea 
e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, both to be administered by ADB. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and office accommodation. ADB will 
be responsible for facilitating implementation and supervision of the TA.  
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
24.  Technical due diligence found the project design robust based on a comprehensive review 
of the feasibility study, cost estimates, and site investigations. The project was appraised based 
on (i) rationale and relevance, benefits, and ease of implementation and operations; (ii) technical 
alternatives, including WWTP technology and decentralized services;33 (iii) least-cost options, 
including capital and operating costs, and achievable cost savings through energy efficiency, 
renewable energy, and climate-resilient measures; (iv) maximizing beneficiary area coverage, 
including unserved rural areas; (v) minimizing adverse environmental and social impacts; and 
(vi) optimizing implementation timelines through high project readiness such as early mobilization 
of detailed design consultants using PRF. A design–build contract modality will support TST with 
a 2-year operation and training period for its capacity building, in addition to institutional support

B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
25.  Economic analysis. The quantified economic benefits of the project are mainly derived 
from two sources: (i) the public health benefits ensuing from being able to access cleaner, safer 
water  in  the  project  area;  and  (ii)  the  global  warming  damages  avoided  through  reduced 
greenhouse gas emissions from the project’s climate-resilient and energy-efficient features. The 
resulting base case economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is 11.43% for the centralized urban 
wastewater systems and 12.78% for the decentralized rural wastewater disposal systems. The 
overall project EIRR is 11.93%. These results confirm that the project is economically viable, 
exceeding ADB’s minimum discount rate of 9%. Sensitivity analysis determined that the project 
EIRRs will remain robust under the following scenarios: (i) a 10% increase in investment costs 
arising from delayed implementation or higher-than-expected inflation; (ii) a 10% increase in O&M 
costs resulting from higher-than-budgeted personnel salaries and other costs; (iii) a 10% decline 
in benefits resulting from lower-than-projected public health and greenhouse gas reduction 
benefits; (iv) a combination of (i), (ii), and (iii); and (v) a delay in project benefits by a year. 
26.  Financial analysis. The financial internal rate of return is 1.58%, which exceeds the 
estimated weighted average cost of capital of 1.44%. Sensitivity analysis shows that financial 
viability will be at risk if a 10% increase in capital costs and a 10% decrease in benefits are 
combined simultaneously with a 1-year delay in increasing wastewater tariffs. To generate a 
positive financial internal rate of return, tariffs would need to be increased by about 27.5% in real 
terms, starting from 2023. Nominally, this means increasing the tariff for residential users from the 
current SUM700 per m3 to SUM1,850 per m3 by 2026. ADB has discussed the proposed increase 
with the Ministry of Finance and TST, and both have agreed that the rate is reasonable. The 
combined  water  and  wastewater  tariffs  would  be  affordable  to  the  targeted  household 
beneficiaries, who have expressed a willingness to pay SUM1,975 per m3 (metered households)34 
and  SUM3,442  per  m3  (non-metered  households)  for  improved  sanitation  services.  The 
government will support TST’s debt servicing, including the foreign exchange risk and tariff 
reforms. TST will be responsible for the O&M of the assets created by the project. Operating loan 
covenants have been formulated and agreed to ensure that TST’s financial performance is 
strengthened, enabling it to use the ADB loan proceeds effectively and efficiently, and to meet 
the project’s O&M requirements. The financial analysis indicates that TST’s projected operating 
ratios, liquidity indicators, and debt servicing coverage ratios will meet the agreed loan covenants. 
C.  Sustainability 
27.  The project supports sustainability through an integrated and inclusive approach, with 
robust technical design and institutional development. Physical investments are based on realistic 
and long-term demand projections, least-cost options, and modern design principles to ensure 
cost-effective,  climate-resilient  investments  with  positive  environmental  and  public  health 
benefits. The operational sustainability of new assets is supported by stronger O&M plans; 
adequate budget allocations; enhanced training, particularly for TST’s operators; strengthening 
of an existing training center; and pilot-testing of private sector engagement for the O&M of the 
WWTPs using a performance-based contract after the completion of a design–build contract, with 
transfer of skills to TST. This gradual public-private partnership initiative approach will help build 
expertise and confidence in the engagement of the private sector. The financial sustainability of 
the investments is supported by improved revenues and reduced operations costs. Recent sector 
reforms, including the creation of the UJSC as the asset owner, will strengthen the utility’s

D.  Governance 
28.  TST, now a subsidiary of UJSC for WSS, was established and registered as a limited 
liability company in 2015 and became a state-owned enterprise in 2016. It is responsible for all 
WSS services in Tashkent Province. 
29.  Financial management. The financial management risk rating of TST is substantial but 
is expected to be moderate after its staff gain experience and receive training under the two 
ongoing ADB-financed water supply projects (footnote 9). The main reasons are that (i) TST is in 
the early stage of implementing its first two ADB-financed projects and has limited experience as 
an  implementing  agency;  and  (ii)  adjustments  are  necessary  to  its  accounting,  budgeting, 
auditing, and reporting systems. TST also lacks experience in managing ADB disbursements and 
the adequate capacity to manage an advance account or statement of expenditure procedures 
following ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2017, as amended from time to time). TST will 
be required to adopt the International Financial Reporting Standards to report its statutory 
financial statements. UJSC,35 with its experience in implementing similar projects through its PCU, 
will supervise and guide TST. The proposed project will also provide financial management 
support to TST.36 
30.  Procurement. The overall risk assessment is medium. In the past, procurement activities 
were often delayed due to procurement capacity issues. The situation has been improved by 
having PCU capacity strengthened through on the job trainings from four ADB-financed projects 
and refresher trainings on ADB procurement policy and procedures, and the use of International 
Federation of Consulting Engineers (FIDIC) books in 2020. The PCU has 18 highly trained and 
experienced  staff  with  extensive  experience  in  procuring  and  implementing  projects  with 
international financial institutions and donor organizations. TST, formerly the provincial suvokova 
(utility) responsible for WSS services in Tashkent Province, will be the implementing agency for 
the project. After experiencing two ADB-financed projects (footnote 9), TST is familiar with ADB 
guidelines and procedures, and its capacity for project implementation has significantly improved. 
TST’s document preparation and review process is adequate to follow ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time). Advance procurement progress is reflected under key 
activities with milestone items 1.1 and 1.3.

The Anticorruption Agency of Uzbekistan was established to implement anticorruption standards 
and mechanisms in all spheres of state and public activities. Integrity due diligence was conducted

E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
32.  Poverty. The project will have a direct impact on the health, economic prospects, and 
living conditions of the population in the project area. By 2028, the project will benefit about 
1 million residents in six cities, one urban center, and the rural areas of three districts, where 25% 
of all households are poor. The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the social and poverty 
issues in the project area, which experiences high unemployment (18%) and gender inequality—
resulting in high rates of violence against women.38 Poor quality drinking water has increased the 
disease burden, with negative economic consequences that disproportionately affect women, the 
poor, and vulnerable groups. Households without proper toilet facilities are more exposed to the 
risk of waterborne diseases. This significantly affects productivity and family health expenditures. 
Only about 26% of households in the project area are connected to sewers;39 the remaining 74% 
rely on pit latrines and earth ditches. Health benefits can be derived from (i) increased access to 
centralized wastewater systems in urban areas, (ii) reduced open defecation in rural areas, and 
(iii) improved septage management. 
33.  Social.  A  community,  gender-friendly,  awareness-raising  campaign  on  WASH+H, 
including COVID-19 prevention practices, will deliver education in rural areas to address local 
sanitation practices that threaten public health and hygiene, including women and girls’ well-being 
and reproductive health, and to strengthen community decision-making and monitoring. Activities 
include (i) training of trainers of a youth foundation and teachers, (ii) conducting behavior change 
campaigns, (iii) community-awareness campaigns through media and engagement activities 
supported  by  a  local  nongovernment  organization,  and  (iv)  supporting  community  hygiene 
monitoring groups. The campaign will build the capacity of community leaders to become hygiene 
promoters and monitor wastewater disposal systems in rural areas.  
34.  Gender. The project is classified effective gender mainstreaming. The findings of the 
gender analysis revealed that women are primarily responsible for domestic chores, and the lack 
of reliable sanitation facilities increases this burden. About 45% of women are responsible for 
water delivery, and 94% for removing solid and liquid domestic waste. About 14% of households 
headed by women and 150 social institutions in the rural areas of Chinaz, Yangiyul, and Zangiota 
districts  lack  access  to  basic  levels  of  clean  water,  sanitation,  and  hygiene,  with  serious 
consequences for reproductive health. The project will reduce the drudgery and time poverty of 
women and girls, enhance public hygiene awareness, including menstrual hygiene management 
practices, and free up their time for educational and employment opportunities that will contribute 
to COVID-19 impact recovery. The project’s specific gender design features include (i) access to 
improved sanitation facilities made available in kindergartens, schools, and polyclinics in rural 
areas; (ii) facilitation of women’s participation in project-associated activities; (iii) employment 
opportunities for women;40 (iv) training in gender-inclusive participatory hygiene and sanitation in 
rural areas; (v) an awareness campaign on WASH+H, with a focus on COVID-19 prevention 
(targeting 50% female participants); (vi) equal opportunity and access to training for female staff;

F.  Safeguards 
35.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.42 
36.  Environment (category B). The project impacts are expected to be limited in magnitude 
and of short duration, mostly related to the rehabilitation of WWTPs and collection networks. 
These impacts include generation of dust, noise, and hazardous solid waste,43 labor and public 
safety,  temporary  access  blockages,  traffic  disturbances,  and  construction  material 
transportation.  UJSC  prepared  an  initial  environmental  examination  report,  including  an 
environmental management plan, which was disclosed on ADB’s website in June 2021. UJSC 
translated the summary of the initial environmental examination report into Uzbek and posted it 
on UJSC’s website, with the full report in Russian, in July 2021. Twelve public consultation 
meetings were conducted in the project area. During operations, the anticipated negative impacts 
caused by the increase in sewage volume will be mitigated by WWTP operations in accordance 
with performance standards. The environmental management plan includes the preparation and 
implementation of a COVID-19 health and safety management plan and emergency response 
plan by contractors, to address the COVID-19 risk on workers and local communities. The project 
will have significant positive environmental impacts, including improved water quality in the 
receiving watercourses of the WWTPs. The project will install 23,500 individual septic tanks in 70 
rural settlements.44 This will eliminate the infiltration of raw sewage to soil and groundwater, 
preventing pollution consequences to the rural water supply. To ensure adequate maintenance 
of the septic tanks installed, the project will provide user’s manuals including information on the 
need for regular desludging of septic tanks, disposal of the septage, service fees, and disposal 
items unsuitable for septic tank systems.   
37.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). The project is expected to have only temporary 
impacts as there are no permanent land acquisition needs. Temporarily, it will likely require 
2.26 hectares (ha) of land, including 1.64 ha of arable and crop cultivation land, and 0.62 ha of 
orchard and garden land to facilitate the construction of the wastewater collection lines in Chinaz 
and Yangiyul districts. Other project components do not have involuntary resettlement impacts. 
The  social  impact  assessment  identifies  four  affected  households  (14  persons)  that  will 
experience temporary impacts. No household will experience a severe impact from loss of 
productive assets and no household has been identified as vulnerable. A draft land acquisition 
and resettlement plan (LARP) has been prepared based on the feasibility study and preliminary 
route  alignment  following  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  relevant  national 
legislation. The LARP was disclosed on ADB’s website on 15 April 2021. Project information 
disclosure and consultations with project stakeholders and affected persons were undertaken 
during LARP preparation and will continue throughout project implementation. When the LARP is 
updated following the detailed design, ADB’s approval will be obtained before its implementation. 
The grievance redress mechanism will assist affected persons in resolving grievances and 
complaints. UJSC will submit semiannual safeguard monitoring reports to ADB for review and
